direction.raw_text: Written by RON SHELTON Based on material by AL STUMP July 1993 Draft FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY Do not go gentle into that good night, Old age should burn and rave at close of day; Rage, rage against the dying of the light. Dylan Thomas Nice guys finish last. Leo Durocher 1   INT. OLD OFFICE (SANTA BARBARA, CA) - DAY (1960)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room is California Spanish, thick walls, arches, and light spills in from a mission window. But we don't have any sense of place just yet. At first there are just details. EXTREME CLOSEUP ON TYPEWRITER KEYS of an old Underwood upright, well-worn and ancient. A woman's fingertips with red nail polish are placed on the keys. They wiggle. CLOSE ON PIPE IN ASHTRAY Smoke curls.   A man's hand picks it up. CLOSE ON MAN'S HAT AND COAT on a coat rack. CLOSE ON WASTE BASKET Overflowing with crunched-up paper. MAN lies on a couch near the window. He stands up suddenly and looks out the window. AL STUMP, 40, is sharply dressed -- tie, dress shirt, cufflinks. He's staring at something. HIS POV - COURTYARD BELOW - BEAUTIFUL BRUNETTE in high heels crosses the courtyard. She glances up toward Stump, then quickly turns away and disappears. CLOSE ON STUMP He sighs, and turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The muse has   not descended, Lucille. (off   her silence) The muse has   not descended. (off   her silence) God damn it,   Lucille, you hear me? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 1   CONTINUED:                                                    1 ANGLE ON LUCILLE The woman at the typewriter, a 50-year old steno/secre- tary, responds calmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The muse has not descended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes! The muse has left me stranded here like a beached whale -- only one phrase, one word, from finishing the greatest essay I've ever written! One word, the right word -- Flaubert called it 'le mot juste' -- I ever tell you that? Lucille is a longsuffering saint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Le mot juste' -- the exact right word the writer needs to tell his story. Yessir, you've mentioned it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hemingway, Faulkner, Joyce -- they all searched for 'le mot juste' until they cried, until they bled...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yessir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this essay about again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fishing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean what is it really about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said it was about the quote unquote primal issues of survival, man against nature, etcetera -- that's what you said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ohyeah... so... we end the essay with... (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 1   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'The tarpon leaps shimmering into the late cross light of the keys, a primeval moment frozen in... (hesitates) ... frozen in'... Lucille types it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shimmering tarpon -- very good, Mr. Stump... (beat) ... 'frozen in' what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, Lucille, that's what the Muse will tell me if she ever descends. (considering) ... 'frozen in'... The PHONE RINGS -- Lucille answers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes? Yes? Just a minute, I'll see if he's available. (covers phone) It's your wife -- are you and she speaking again? Stump's cavalier attitude stops cold.     He starts to reach for the phone, then stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dunno.   How does she sound?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't ask me to interpret. Stump is suddenly a nervous wreck.     He hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her... tell her... I'll talk... no... tell her I'm out -- I'll call her later... (serious, dark) God damn it. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 1   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Apparently he's out, Mrs. Stump -- I'll have him call you back. She hangs up.    The mood has shifted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about 'le mot juste,' Mr. Stump?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck 'le mot juste,' Lucille! Finish the damn thing yourself. 'The primeval moment is frozen in' whatever the hell you want it to be. Did you know that James Joyce let his secretary -- none other than Samuel Beckett -- revise and edit Molly's solliloquy in Ulysses? You're my Beckett -- I give you 'le mot juste!' Just get the damn thing in the mail so I can get paid. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Problems with the Mrs.? Stump reaches for a beat-up pogo stick which leans against the wall in his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.    I need a drink. He grabs his hat and coat and we begin hearing the number one hit song of 1960, PERCY FAITH'S schmaltzy recording of "A Summer Place."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 2   EXT. DOWNTOWN STREET - LATE AFTERNOON                          2 Stump pogo sticks down the sidewalk, tipping his hat to pedestrians. They're not alarmed. He's the town eccentric. He pogos across a street and towards -- CUT TO: 5. 3   EXT. THE SPORTSMAN'S LOUNGE - LATE AFTERNOON              3 A watering hole like a million others.   He pogo sticks right in the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Stumpy... Stump addresses the sportswriters at the table as if they were a small audience in a lounge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Awright, awright... how do you get five old ladies to say 'fuck?'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeez, I dunno, how? Etc...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yell 'bingo.' Stump laughs. The others groan. REYNALDO, 40's, black, speaks up. He's one of the regulars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, I got one -- (beat) A drunk is taking a piss in front of a bar, a bus drives by, real fast right along the curb, and knocks his thing off. Drunk picks up his thing, puts it in his pocket, goes into a bar, reaches into his pocket and puts his thing on the bar. 'Look't that,' he says, 'bus knocked my thing off.' Bartender says, 'that ain't your thing -- that's a cigar butt.' (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 4   CONTINUED:                                                    4 REYNALDO (CONT'D) Drunk reaches into his other pocket and slaps another thing on the bar. 'There,' he says, 'bus knocked my thing off.' Bartender says, 'you're drunk and that ain't your thing either. That's another cigar butt.' (beat) Drunk looks down at both cigar butts and back up at the bartender and says, 'God damn it, I mushta smoked my dick.' Everyone roars, even Stump. But Frank, as usual, is hyper serious and never quite gets into the revelry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amidst this levity, gentlemen, I have some real concerns. Mark my words, people will look back on this year and say that 1960 was the year that Western Civilization began its downward trajectory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You need to get laid, Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guys, guys, c'mon... do you really think things are as good as they used to be? You think Jack Kennedy is qualified to be President?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kennedy may not be qualified, but
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 4   INT. THE SPORTSMAN'S - LATE AFTERNOON                     4 A classic city bar, a hangout for drunks, philosophers, and especially sportswriters and journalists. Our man hops off his pogo stick -- nobody even notices, and joins his cronies, five sportswriters full of dogmatic opinions on every subject known to man. FRANK, a sportswriter, is at the jukebox feeding quarters. He looks up routinely, they're all regulars here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jackie's a babe -- and that's good enough for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're a happily married couple and that oughta stand for something these days... Every man nods in solemn agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Speaking of being happily married, Al, are you and your old lady still having problems? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 4   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no, the wife and I are all patched up -- doin' fantastic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good to hear... awright... way to go, Stumpy... (Etc.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean look at us -- we call ourselves writers but we just watch ballgames and get drunk a lot. You call that writing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the department store of life, sports is the toy department -- so what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, besides, Alan here's writing a serious novel, aren't ya?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well I haven't started yet but I'm gonna. I've been busy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You guys are pathetic. Ya write for one reason -- a paycheck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More art was created for money than for passion. Take your platitudes and shove 'em, Frank. I'm gonna write a novel too, someday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Great American Novel, I suppose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It could come from my pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a barbershop writer, Al -- you write sugar-coated pieces for guys to skim when they're waiting for a haircut! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 4   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Awright, that's it! Let's go! Settle this right here! Stump raises his fists as if to fight; Frank responds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! A scuffle breaks out, a lot of posturing, feinting, but they're all too chicken to do anything. Nobody wants to fight. A PHONE RINGS at the bar. The bartender answers the phone, shouts at the obnoxious sportwriters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stump!   For you. Stump goes to the phone, interrupting his own "fight."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phone call saved your ass. Stump grabs the phone, covering an ear to hear better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... yeah... who?... no... you're kidding?... when? Stump hangs up the phone and turns. His face registers shock, or more precisely, bewilderment and wonder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey... (as they ignore him) Shut up! They do, and give Stump their ruffled attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cobb wants to see me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cobb who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ty Cobb!    How many Cobbs are there?! This news instantly sobers the room. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 4   CONTINUED:    (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ty Cobb?   I thought he was dead?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not yet. He said he wants to tell me the real story of his life before he croaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were just talking to Ty Cobb?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Georgia Peach himself. This impresses the hell out of everyone in the room.           Even Stump is still a little dazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They say Cobb is crazy. The meanest sonofabitch who ever lived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard he killed a man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe so, but -- he was the greatest baseball player of them all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, the best, no one close, etc... Frank suddenly is cautionary, concerned, paternal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, Al, be careful -- STUMP I ain't gettin' my ass shot, don't worry...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not that -- the story. (beat) This is like Ivan the Terrible inviting somebody into the Czar's palace before he died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Except Ivan was a nicer guy... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 4   CONTINUED:    (5)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't let Cobb bullshit you. This is your shot. This is all our shot. (as cronies agree) When does he want to see you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gathered all the film footage that existed on Cobb -- which wasn't much -- and rented the local theater for the afternoon... (beat)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 5   INT. NEARLY EMPTY MOVIE THEATER - DAY                        5 Al Stump sits alone in the theater, except for a teenaged boy sweeping the aisles, who stops to watch the screen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: too, had thought that the great Ty Cobb had been dead for awhile... 6   ANGLE ON SCREEN                                              6 The screen fills with (B&W) Movietone Newsreel footage of Ty Cobb, complete with overly sincere NARRATION and MUSIC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This 1905 cameo of an 18-year-old youth shows a peaches-and-cream complexion and the piercing eyes of a lad who would become, etc... Onscreen (B&W) -- Cobb as a young ballplayer followed by images of Cobb's famous batting stance, Cobb clowning, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His reputation as being difficult at best, psychotic at worst, preceded him. But if there was one thing I knew after all my years as a journalist covering politicians, celebrities, and sports heroes, it was this -- (CONTINUED) 11. 6   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Onscreen (B&W) -- Cobb with children, Cobb with celebri- ties, Cobb in a parade honoring him, and always, Cobb's dashing, swashbuckling style of play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The 'facts' -- and public perception of those 'facts' -- frequently bear little resemblance. Onscreen (B&W) -- Cobb in action -- His demon fury gives way to the fierce joy of his playing. He slashes a ball up the alley, turns first and never hesitates at second, and as the relay comes into third -- STUMP (V.O.) One thing was beyond argument -- he was the most brilliant athlete of his time... perhaps of any time. (beat) I was determined to find out who was the real Ty Cobb. Cobb slides with spikes high and a cloud of dust. There is something thrilling and terrifying in the image.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 7 Stump's car, a late model Buick, moves across the stunning grasslands at the western base of the Sierra Nevadas. We begin hearing his voice, then see him inside the car driving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They said Cobb owned property all over the country, but in recent years had been staying in his hunting lodge at Lake Tahoe in the Sierra Nevadas. 9   AERIAL SHOT - LONE PAIR OF HEADLIGHTS                         9 moving up into the Sierras, into rugged terrain and thick forests.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 10   INT. CAR - DUSK                                             10 Stump straining to see the road, a bit wary of this drive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Driving into the Sierras at night with winter coming on wasn't the smartest decision I'd ever made but it seemed better than being late for my first meeting with Cobb. First drops of rain begin hitting the windshield -- Stump hits the wiper button and the floppy blades begin ineffectively wiping the windshield. Stump struggles with his vision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit... POV SHOT THROUGH WINDSHIELD A dismal, wet and obscured view of the mountain road, climbing higher into the Sierras. A small roadside gas station comes INTO VIEW, and -- Stump pulls his car into the station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 11 Stump gets out, blows on his hands. It's cold, and a man comes out, the gas station owner, JONAH, 55. The man services the car throughout the conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fill it up and replace the wiper blades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colder than a witch's tit, eh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just starting. We got three- four feet of snow another thousand feet up. Where ya going? Skiing? I hate skiing. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 11   CONTINUED:                                                      11 STUMP Actually, I'm going to meet Ty Cobb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cobb?! He stopped here for gas once, I asked him for an autograph for my boy and he told me to shove it where the sun don't shine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear he's got a way with kids... Stump heads to a pay phone as the attendant replaces the wiper blades. Stump's breath hangs heavy in the air. It's cold. Freezing. He drops a set of coins in the call box. He blows on his hands and pulls up his collar -- he wasn't prepared for the weather to be this cold. He comes to life when he hears a voice on the other end -- a voice we never hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, baby, it's me... (beat) Al... your husband... (beat) I'm up in the woods somewhere on assignment... (beat) Listen, sweetheart, listen -- nobody can love you the way I love you and I want you to take me back. I made a mistake. (listens) Okay, lots of mistakes. I know I'm not worthy. We hear a CLICK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey?   Sweetheart?   Baby? He flicks the receiver hook several times.       She's gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 12   EXT. MOUNTAIN ROAD - NIGHT                                      12 RAIN POUNDS down as the car climbs to higher elevation. CUT TO: 14. 13   INT. CAR - NIGHT (RAINY)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I confess I was looking forward to seeing Cobb and being near his brilliance. My own life seemed on hold, somehow. Everyday churning out the same old articles, drinking at 4 in the afternoon with the same old guys, the same old excuses for not writing a novel, the same old confused marriages that we all needed and were trying to get out of at the same time... Cobb was a god whose brilliance, however difficult, could rub off on me. His problems were different than mine... 14   ANGLE ON STUMP'S CAR                                        14 which pulls off the road and heads up a small mountain road among snow-covered pines. A row of mailboxes catches Stump's attention, and he pulls over to review the names with a flashlight. He lights his way across the names of a dozen boxes -- nothing, until: The last box, enormously oversized, bears the name "COBB." CLOSE ON STUMP He smiles.    Perfect. BACK TO SCENE His car heads up a mountain road a final hundred yards, comes around a bend in the trees and there it is -- 15. 14   POV SHOT - HUGE MOUNTAIN LODGE                              14 In the grand style but, like the mailbox, grotesquely oversized.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck you, Mr. Cobb, I have too much dignity to spend another moment with you. I hope you die before the sun comes up and may you rot in hell! The man whirls and is shocked to see Stump standing there with his own suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a writer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean he actually found somebody to take the job? Willie bursts out into crazed laughter, as if the world of Cobb was finally too absurd. Cobb and a writer? In this weather? In any weather? And the man walks through the rain, laughing, heading on foot down off the mountain as Stump just stares. Stump turns and steps into the open doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 16   INT. MOUNTAIN LODGE - NIGHT                                    16 Stump in the front door -- The place is enormous and barely lit. Taxidermied game hangs on the wall. Stump is terrified. A MAN is sitting in an overstuffed chair reading a news- paper. Dressed in a business suit and tie, he seems oblivious to the surrounding chaos. He also seems out of place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Cobb? The man looks at Stump and points upstairs without speaking. More CRASHING sounds from upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Cobb? The silence is shattered by a SCRATCH, then VIOLIN MUSIC from upstairs. STATIC suggests a record is playing. 17   ANGLE ON STAIRS                                                17 Stump climbs the stairs with caution -- Until he's just outside the half open door from which light spills. He hesitates...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?   Mr. Cobb? A GUNSHOT RINGS OUT -- Ripping through the door.       Stump is terrified -- he gasps for air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you very much, Mr. Cobb, but I don't need this job that bad. Stump turns and creeps back toward the stairs, but -- ANOTHER GUNSHOT RINGS OUT -- SHATTERING a hanging LAMP. Stump freeses one more time.     Silence.   Then the voice -- COBB Yes, Mr. Stump -- you do need this job that bad. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 17   CONTINUED:                                                      17 COBB (CONT'D) (beat) Now come in here and meet the great Ty Cobb. (calmly) I won't hurt you. Stump breathes deeply and steps into the doorway -- He does it as if there's no choice, accepting his fate. And sees: 18   POV SHOT - TY COBB                                              18 Lying in bed in a robe. Unshaven. Bottles of booze and food everywhere. And bottles of pills sit on every surface. Two hunting dogs sit on the bed with him. A small record player sits next to he bed. A record spins, filling the room with FRITZ KREISLER VIOLIN SOLOS. He places the gun on      his night table, knocking pills and bottles to the floor      with a crash he barely notices. When he speaks it is      without a snarl, without threat -- simply, even sweetly,      he says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the violin -- Fritz Kreisler. I'm a great admirer of his. I'm also a great admirer of yours. BACK TO SCENE STUMP Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you are a hopeless romantic and only a moderate success.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, I am the most successful sportswriter in America and not merely a 'moderate success.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. (beat) Give me those pills over there. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 18   CONTINUED:                                                     18 Stump retrieves some pills that Cobb is pointing towards. Cobb washes down a handful of pills with a bottle of Scotch. Momentarily revitalized, Cobb hands Stump a folded letter which Stump opens to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's an invitation to a testimonial dinner at the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, New York. You're taking me there -- when is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the great ones will be there -- The great Mickey Cochrane will be there! Hornsby, Sisler, Ott, the Waner Brothers... we used to have some parties, Stump, I'll tell ya that right now... (beat) We can't forget.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't forget.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at me closely, Al... (with utmost sincerity) Lie after lie has been written about me -- my whole life I've been misunderstood. (beat) You're gonna tell the real story of Ty Cobb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the 'real' story? Cobb climbs slowly out of bed.     His words are reasoned and not without passion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why you're here. (beat) See, there's two kinds of writers. The kind that spin endless yarns about small subjects... that's you. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 18   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or... there's the kind with one great subject that consumes them forever. (beat) That could be you. Because I am that subject. Cobb hobbles to a table in front of a window. The table is covered with pills, bottles, needles, and booze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jameson! Get your ass up here! Cobb grabs another bottle of booze and swigs deeply, liquor spilling over him. Then, suddenly, he holds up his hand. A calm comes over him as -- He stares out the window into the snowy woods.       His rage has quickly turned into a quiet, intense, unsettling focus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mmmmmm... 19   POV SHOT - WOODS IN MOONLIGHT                                     19 near the lodge. A bank of snow -- and a large buck moves INTO VIEW. 20   CLOSE ON COBB'S FACE                                              20 His eyes light.     A flare in his nostrils.    A twitch.     And utter calm. BACK TO SCENE Jameson, the man in the suit, arrives and stands in the back of the room. He takes notes when Cobb speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir? Cobb continues staring out the window at the buck. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 20   CONTINUED:                                                         20 COBB There's a small oil company near Bakersfield called Honolulu Oil, sitting near the Elk Hills Reserve... (beat) I want you to buy all the stock you can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honolulu Oil?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Getty is expanding in the west, looking for companies like that. I got a hunch... (beat) Stumpy, c'mere... Cobb picks up the revolver and holds it lovingly. Stump crosses and stands behind Cobb, sharing the view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can take that buck.     What'ya think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a pistol? No way. Cobb smiles and loads the revolver.       He pushes the window which swings slowly open. 21   POV SHOT - BUCK IN MOONLIGHT                                       21 searches for leaves to eat in the snow.          Serene.   Unaware. BACK TO SCENE COBB (to Jameson) There's a board meeting of Coca-Cola in Georgia next week. Call them up and tell them I can't make it for medical -- (correcting himself)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: personal -- reasons... (beat) ... and sell all the 3-M stock we got.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 22   COBB                                                           22 raises the gun -- he wobbles badly and steadies himself. The gun shakes. Then steadies. Stump stands over his shoulder watching the bizarre action. 23   POV SHOT - BUCK RAISES ITS HEAD                                23 Just as... KABLAM!   The REVOLVER FIRES with a violent kick. The buck spins and runs back into the woods, kicking snow and disappearing in the brush. 24   BACK TO SCENE                                                  24 COBB Got him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like hell you did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right behind the ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're full of shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jameson?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If Mr. Cobb said he got him, then he got him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have no vision, Stump. A writer without vision is a waste of my time. I think I picked the wrong man. Cobb stumbles back into bed, somewhat exhausted by the ordeal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I think I better get back to San Francisco before the storm hits. I'll take care of these transactions, Mr. Cobb. And Jameson exits the room. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 24   CONTINUED:                                                    24 STUMP And I'll be leaving as well, sir, since you think I'm the wrong man for the job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up, Stump -- we both know that I'm your meal ticket. (beat) We need each other. (smiles) And we start in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Cobb reaches over and defiantly turns UP the MUSIC so that the room is overwhelmed with Kreisler's violin. Stump stares back at this decrepit, overpowering figure. Cobb gradually slips into sleep, buried in the music, the booze, the pills, the pain...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't be around the man for long without needing a break, which his painkillers gracefully provided. Stump lights a pipe as he walks up a trail, away from the lodge, toward a ridge, all covered with snow. The flurries of snow are getting thicker now.

Statistics that haven't been approached in three-quarters of a century. Stump stops at the ridge and looks down at the partially frozen Lake Tahoe in the lingering light.

direction.raw_text: But I'd known boxing champions and football players -- they were gentle souls outside the arena. (beat) How much of Cobb was an act, a lifetime of theatrical intimidation to preserve his own legend? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

Tough guys are tougher, women more beautiful, routine acts of self-preservation become heroic. Stump continues walking down a crest of snow, through a stand of snow-covered pines. The light is dark, purple, eerie, and Stump is lost in thought, until, suddenly, he sees: A trail of blood in the snow. He follows it down a slope, past a tree, growing deeper, thicker. And there it is -- The buck lies dead in the snow in a pool of blood. Stump stops in fear, then approaches, leans down and examines -- STUMP My God... The buck's head has a hole blasted behind the ear. Stump rises quickly to his feet and looks around. The woods are silent. Snow falls from a branch. And... dialogue.raw_text: Confetti falls from the sky -- PROFESSOR COBB, 40, Ty's father, waves to the crowd in front of city hall. Signs everywhere declare him to be the newly elected MAYOR COBB. A band plays "Sweet Georgia Brown" as the Mayor makes a victory speech.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Professor Cobb sings loudly with the Deacons behind the Pastor as the CONGREGATION joins in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Young Ty Cobb is baptized in the river.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Young Ty and three buddies walk along the track.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Other trains on other tracks bearing down on young Cobb. In each case -- Young Cobb dances in the track and leaps with grace to safety. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The head of a horse in f.g., shaking its head, uncomfort- able with the bit in its mouth. In the b.g., the gabled house in the moonlight. A small light spills from a second- floor window onto the balcony. A man on the balcony porch moves toward the window from which light spills. The man pulls up the window and -- KABLAM! A SHOTGUN BLAST rips the silence and darkness. The man falls on his back. KABLAM!   A second SHOTGUN BLAST takes off his head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 53   INT. CAR ON HIGHWAY - DUSK                                   53 Stump is stunned by this information as the car careens wildly down the mountainside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (B&W) A gambling den. Money on the bench. Two men is suits are placing bets, intermingling with the players. A player smokes, another drinks -- this is as far from the anti- septic modern game as can be imagined. Cobb, early 20's, selects his bat, talks to the gambler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Single to left, steal second, steal third, steal home...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eight to one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten to one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're on. Cobb tosses some money on the pile, and climbs up the dugout steps, shouting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 55   EXT. ON-DECK CIRCLE - DAY (B&W)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, greaseball, check your wife
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: one of the players is missing! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 55   CONTINUED:                                                   55 The pitcher flips Cobb the finger and takes a sign, deliv- ering a pitch which is swung on and missed, strike three. Cobb heads to the plate, passing his dejected teammate who has just struck out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who the hell ever signed you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to hell. Cobb laughs -- He seems to feed on these exchanges, and he stands in at the plate, addressing the UMPIRE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Cyclops, you're missing a good game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up, Cobb. As Cobb digs in, he reaches into his back pocket and drops something on home plate, in front of the CATCHER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here ya go... The Catcher holds up a pair of women's panties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your old lady left 'em in my car last night -- I thought you could give 'em back to her. CLOSE ON CATCHER He flips his thumb, a sign for the pitcher to deck Cobb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going down, Cobb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go. The pitcher delivers a fastball right at Cobb's head -- He hits the dirt just before the pitch arrives (and this is long before players wore protective headgear). Cobb rises, laughing defiantly. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 55   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's as hard as you can throw?! Shit, it that was my fastball I'd wear a dress! Then Cobb shouts at the shortstop, a large German-American athlete, the great HONUS WAGNER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Wagner! I'd shade me a little up the middle if I was you! Wagner doesn't budge, comfortable in his position, not drawn into Cobb's taunts. Stoic, implacable -- far from Cobb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You try to take my head off then you throw a sinker away, in and out, same old shit -- sinker away... CLOSE ON COBB His chatter stops, his focus is intense and sudden. He holds the bat strangely, with a split grip, a left- handed batter, he dangles the bat almost parallel to the ground. For all his fierceness, there's a delicacy in the way he holds the bat. A baton, a paintbrush, a magic wand... NEW ANGLE Here comes the pitch -- sinker away -- and Cobb unleashes a swing that is at once quick and powerful. He drives the ball to left, the opposite way -- Wagner lunges to his right -- But the ball skips into left. Cobb streaks to first and rounds the base viciously, daring to stretch it into a double but slamming on the brakes and returning to first when the throw rifles into second. Cobb shouts defiantly at the pitcher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You God damn coward! You shoulda thrown at me again! You shoulda hit me in the fucking head! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 55   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Krauthead, I'm coming down. CLOSE ON WAGNER He just nods. NEW ANGLE The pitcher stretches, looks and delivers -- and Cobb breaks for second. The pitch is wide. The Catcher fires. Wagner takes the throw as Cobb arrives in a spikes-up slide. And Wagner swipes a brutal tag in Cobb's face -- his giant ham of a hand in the tiny glove clutching the ball lashes across Cobb's mouth. Blood gushes. The ball pops free. Wagner seems unbothered by the fact that Cobb is safe at second -- he has bloodied Cobb's face. Cobb seems unboth- ered by the fact that his face is a bloody mess -- he has stolen second. Both men seem satisfied. BACK IN DUGOUT More money is wagered. PITCHER Stretches and delivers -- Cobb takes off for third.       The throw is high -- he slides in safely. IN STANDS Bets are doubled. The stands are full of wagering. The whole ballpark is like a giant saloon -- drinking, smoking, wagering -- and the game is played by thugs and brigands. COBB ON THIRD Yells at the pitcher and Catcher. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 55   CONTINUED:    (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want in on the action? My mother has a better arm than you! (to the Catcher) I'm coming to you, greaseball! Coming to kick your dago ass! CATCHER steals a glance at Cobb who takes a menacing lead off third. The Catcher gives a signal to the pitcher. PITCHER nods, winds up, and as he does -- Here comes Cobb with a recklessness beyond reason. And as the pitch arrives in the Catcher's hands, the Catcher digs in to take on Cobb -- Cobb slides spikes high, flying above the earth, his back leg slashing his spikes like knives. It is a slide of utter defiance and violence, a slide intended to harm. A vicious collision between Cobb and the catcher -- blood and dust. The ball rolls free. Safe. Cobb and the catcher immediately start punching and in seconds, a brawl breaks out, both benches clearing. As the police rush out to break up the brawl...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In those days you didn't hold hands and dance with the men on the other teams. They were the enemy -- you fought with 'em. (beat) And I was the most hated man in baseball. 56   EXT. PHILADELPHIA BALLPARK - DAY (B&W)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a shit, Cobb! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 56   CONTINUED:                                                     56 Cobb continues warming up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate your guts, Cobb! Cobb tips his hat and speaks easily to the fan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A good day to you, too, sir... The police escort Cobb to right field -- the roar of the vitriolic crowd increases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know what it's like to be booed like that? Cobb in right with the cops -- the crowd on its feet, booing so loudly that the air is all one giant, wailing moan of hatred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It feels wonderful! They couldn't live without me! They came to the ballpark to see me! 57   INT. HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT (B&W)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifty thousand fans trying to kill me everywhere I went! 58   EXT. PHILADELPHIA BALLPARK - DAY       (B&W)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 58   CONTINUED:                                                     58 CLOSE ON COBB He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I loved it. Only great men are booed. Captains of industry and presidents. I knew 'em all... 59   EXT. WHITE HOUSE (C. 1920)    (B&W)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woodrow Wilson had the best Scotch... 60   INT. WHITE HOUSE STUDY (B&W)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warren Harding had the best broads... 61   INT. WHITE HOUSE STUDY (B&W)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Calvin Coolidge wasn't any damn fun at all... CLOSE ON COBB'S MOUTH during the portrait.    We can read his lips as he mouths "fuck you" silently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 50. 62   INT. CAR CAREENING DOWN MOUNTAINSIDE - DUSK                62 Like an out of control bobsled -- Cobb races and Stump hangs on for his life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After World War Two, General Patton asked me for an autograph
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Cobb swings the bat and shouts at the pitcher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cobb looks down at Wagner who stands implacably at short- stop, a large, powerfully-built man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cobb enters the stadium through the dugout. The crowd rises to boo Cobb. The boos are overpowering. Cobb warms up in front of the dugout. The boos are deafening. The vindictive threats are ceaseless.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cobb opens a stack of mail -- a police chief and subor- dinate officers are with him. CLOSE ON MAIL Cut-out letters read:    "COBB - YOU'RE DEAD" Cobb puffs on a cigar defiantly as he reads his hate mail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Armed police patrol the stands looking for snipers as Cobb plays the game in right field surrounded by police. The booing increases -- fans truly hate him. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . WHITE HOUSE STUDY Woodrow Wilson and Cobb have a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Harding, Cobb and others play cards. A lot of money is on the table. And booze. And women that look suspi- ciously like they've been hired. A floozy drapes herself around President Harding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A formal portrait with President Calvin Coolidge and Cobb. Coolidge doesn't smile, doesn't seem to do any- thing. Just another portrait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: he said he patterned himself after me! (beat) Are you getting this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why aren't you writing?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Cause I'm trying to have a good grip on things when this car goes over the next cliff! I ain't ready to die yet! Cobb's tone changes suddenly -- he questions Stump with- out guile or anger, as if his answer is obvious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But neither am I. Cobb stares at Stump, waiting for an answer, and forgets about the road. Stump looks up in fear and points at the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ty! Cobb swerves wildly back onto the road, such as it exists in the blizzard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said I'm not ready to die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then watch the fucking road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're not listening to me! I may have every God damn disease known to man but I am never going to check into a hospital because I am alive and I am going to get laid in Reno! (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 62   CONTINUED:                                                      62 COBB (CONT'D) (beat) You're gonna get laid, too, Stumpy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I don't wanta get laid!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You queer?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you were divorced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're in the middle of a... problem. We're talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talking my ass! Quit hanging on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: get a divorce. Is that why you don't wanta get laid in Reno? 'Cause you're feeling loyal to a woman you're divorcing? That's really stupid, Stumpy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not getting a divorce.    I'm being loyal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that why you used to wine and dine that little brunette who had an office across the courtyard from you in Santa Barbara? Stump is nailed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you know about her?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do my homework, Stumpy. I know where the bodies are buried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It didn't last long! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 62   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey,   no need to defend yourself. When   it comes to women I'm a total shit   -- the difference is, Stumpy, that   I know I'm a shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody knows about the brunette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our little secret, huh? (beat) And that part about me being a shit with women? That ain't gonna be in the book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gotta put your family in my book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your book?! My book! And nothing about my ex-wives or children are gonna be in it. My book is about baseball!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My book is about Cobb!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cobb is baseball! INTERCUT: 63   EXT. HIGHWAY                                                   63 Suddenly something appears ahead on the roadside. Cobb doesn't see it. Stump does. It looks like a figure, huddled, wrapped, immobile in the swirling snow. It can't be...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ty!    Look!   It's a man! THEIR POV - FIGURE attempts to wave at the car. A nearly-frozen, desperate attempt to flag down the car. BACK TO SCENE COBB Fuck him... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 63   CONTINUED:                                                      63 STUMP Stop the car! Cobb brakes -- the car spins to a stop some distance past the figure standing knee-deep in snow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoever it is he's gotta be pretty stupid to be out in this shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're out in this shit! And Stump climbs out of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 64   EXT. SIDE OF ROAD (BLIZZARD) - DUSK                             64 Stump trudges back to the half-frozen figure who flails his arms stiffly at the apparition of a car in all this. The figure is wrapped in blankets, his head covered. We cannot see who it is until we are in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Help me.   Please help me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My God... it's you.     Are you okay? It is Willie, the black man who Cobb fired the day before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe you found me...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me help you to the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you that you'd only last one day with the bastard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cobb's in the car. He's driving. Willie stops trudging toward the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Cobb's in the car?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 64   CONTINUED:                                                      64 WILLIE Then I'm not getting in the car with that son of a bitch. I'd rather take my chances out here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're coming! And Stump drags Willie to the car, though the man is re- luctant the whole way, he is in no condition to resist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hates me. He hates black people...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fucking hates everybody. Don't give him the pleasure of dying out here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If dying out here gives him pleasure then I won't die out here. They get to the car -- Stump opens the back door to help the nearly-frozen man into the car. Cobb grumbles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ty, it's Willie. We can give him a lift to town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullshit! I ain't givin' no nigger a ride nowhere!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 65   INT. STUMP'S CAR - DUSK                                         65 And Stump loses it -- he grabs Cobb's pistol off the seat of the car and aims it right at Cobb's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut the fuck up and give him a ride!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now who's the coward! You won't shoot me! You need me! Stump hands the gun to Willie..... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 65   CONTINUED:                                                     65 STUMP No. But I'm sure Willie would take great pleasure in it. Willie climbs into the back seat with the gun.       Cobb is livid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll pay for this, Stumpy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say, Willie, you a baseball fan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yessir...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's the greatest ballplayer of all time, in your opinion?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie Mays, no doubt about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That nigger couldn't hold my jock!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, Mr. Cobb, the man is speaking... 66   NEW ANGLE                                                      66 And Cobb jumps on the gas -- the car races off, back down the mountain, fishtailing as it goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'd say the second greatest player of all time is Jackie Robinson... or maybe Josh Gibson...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And of course, the greatest base runner of all time isn't riding in this car -- the fastest baseball player of all time was Cool Papa Bell -- Cool Papa would've easily broke all your stolen base records -- (CONTINUED) 56. 66   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Noooooo!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cool Papa   was so fast that when he entered a   hotel room and flipped the light   switch off, he'd be asleep in   bed before it got dark...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then there's Satchel Paige...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yeah, Satchel Paige could throw a porkchop past a wolf, Mr. Cobb, ol' Satchel woulda had you eatin' outta his hand, he woulda had you hittin' .220 and kissin' his black ass to boot...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut this man up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man with the gun does the talking, you wretched, old prick... 67   LONG SHOT - CAR                                                67 racing down the highway in the snow, and we go      out hearing Willie recount the greatest ballplayers      of all time -- all of them black -- as Cobb seethes, a      gun to his head. Stump feeds Willie, watching Cobb's       racism simmer. Into the storm the car disappears -- fishtailing down the mountain. The blizzard grows thicker, the flurries taking over the mountain, until all we see is -- The thick snow falling from the dark sky.      Suddenly -- STUMP Ice!   Slow down! Tyyyy! 68   POV - STEEP DOWNGRADE                                          68 as slick as a bobsled run. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 68   CONTINUED:                                                    68 CLOSE ON STUMP Terror. CLOSE ON WILLIE Terror.   He lowers the gun and hangs on for dear life. CLOSE ON COBB He accelerates with vengeance. 69   CAR                                                           69 wobbles and starts spinning -- out of control, then spinning continuous 360s down the grade. 70   CLOSE ON THREE MEN                                            70 The world spins around them as they cling for their lives. Until: THUD -- the car slams into a bank of snow.      Suddenly, silence. The three men sit without speaking for several beats, slowly acknowledging that they have survived. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fucked up roads. They don't build highways like they used to. 71   POV - HOTEL SIGN IN DISTANCE                                  71 glows a welcome sign in the night.    It is no longer snowing. BACK TO SCENE WILLIE Well, Mr. Cobb, thank you for a lift into town... Willie hands the gun to Stump and climbs out of the car, bidding farewell to Stump as he does. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 71   CONTINUED:                                                   71 WILLIE And you, sir, should leave this disgusting, wretched, sorry son of a bitch immediately. Good evening. Willie tips his hat and trudges to the neon glow in the distance. Cobb and Stump alone in the car. They both look out -- the car is buried, hood deep, in the bank of snow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two rooms, please... The woman turns to confront the two men.     Now we see her. On a fabulous platinum-blonde wig is stuck    a yellow slicker-type rain hat. The ear flaps are     awry, the platinum-blonde wig curls up around it --    the effect is thrilling. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 73   CONTINUED:                                                    73 WOMAN IN WIG Stand back, you old farts. I'm in the middle of something -- (back to clerk) The heat's on the blink and the mattress is lumpy -- I want a discount.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aw, c'mon, you always want a discount, Mona.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ra-mona... and the mattress is always lumpy -- Cobb pulls out a bottle of pills and washes a handful down with a deep swig from a pint bottle of whiskey. The Clerk looks on with alarm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, I've gotta get him checked in. He's very sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're all sick in the eyes of God
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but some of us still have manners. She whirls and leaves the lobby, leaving the three men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two rooms, next to each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ; 74   INT. COBB'S ROOM - NIGHT                                      74 Stump helps Cobb shoot up with insulin -- The needle clumsily groping for a vein in the old man's arm. CLOSE ON COBB His face looks terrible, drawn, drained. Cobb reaches into his pouch and pulls out a bundle of cash and security notes, tied neatly with a string.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My money... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 74   CONTINUED:                                                   74 STUMP Your money's okay, Ty, right here...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My gun...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your gun's okay, too... right here... And Stump hands Cobb his beloved pistol, which Cobb takes with great affection and comfort. Stump helps Cobb into bed, covering him with a blanket. The gun and the money sit on the pillow next to his head. Cobb speaks with great pain just before he passes out from pain, drugs, and exhaustion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We haven't missed the testimonial dinner, have we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No we haven't missed the dinner...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, good... Cobb manages a small, pained smile before drifting off into sleep. Stump turns off the light and exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Happy Birthday! It's your Daddy! Yeah! (beat) Your birthday was yesterday?! No, it couldn't be! Stump quickly checks a calendar on the wall and realizes he's missed his son's birthday. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 75   CONTINUED:                                                   75 STUMP (on phone) Omigod, what can I say? I feel terrible -- no, it's not okay, jeez... When I get off the road we'll do something special -- a late birthday, eh? Maybe you can go to spring training or something with me, eh? Yeah... (beat) Listen, is your mother there? (beat) I know she doesn't want to speak to me, but I want to speak to her. (waits for answer) Okay, okay -- I feel terrible about the birthday... I'll call you real soon. And tell your mother I'm not drinking anymore. Okay... 'bye, 'bye... Stump hangs up the phone -- Takes a deep breath, and... He pours another drink, and sits down to his typewriter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck it... Stump is hunkered over his typewriter pounding away.       His VOICE OVER indicates what he is writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was a fool for thinking Cobb's brilliance might be what I needed at this moment of my life... Ty Cobb was the last thing I needed. (beat) He was not misunderstood -- he was understood perfectly well. He hated blacks, he hated Jews, he hated Catholics -- he hated everything except himself and his own view of the world... (beat) At times it seemed like he would drop dead in front of me... (beat) ... and other times he seemed indestructible... (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 75   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was reluctant to view the great Ty Cobb as a pathetic character, lost in the past, paranoia, and the shallow defense of 'his own breeding'... We hear SOUNDS of the TYPEWRITER BANGING away as... We DRIFT OUT the window -- Leaving Stump to write all night, at first viewing through the window, then moving until we have a view of -- 76   EXT. VIEW OF RENO - NIGHT                                      76 We hear the incessant BANGING OF the TYPEWRITER GRADUALLY FADE AWAY...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 77   INT. STUMP'S ROOM AT HOTEL - DAY                               77 Stump asleep -- full sun shines in the window.       Noon. A BOTTLE CRASHES against the headboard jarring Stump to consciousness. He looks up to see: Cobb reading the pages in a rage.     He tears them as he does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Pathetic, paranoid, lost in the past!' What is this shit?! Stump awakens slowly, disoriented, amidst a shattered bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those are my notes!   You can't look at my notes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're notes -- my life! You're gonna betray me, you son of a bitch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want the truth?   I'm gonna tell the truth! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 77   CONTINUED:                                                   77 COBB Whose truth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine, for crissakes, I'm the writer!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I'm the legend and legends are not pathetic!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These are just notes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you understand anything about 'greatness'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you should find another writer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's not enough time left. This frank admission momentarily stops Stump.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm entitled to my opinions -- COBB Now that's pathetic. Who gives a good God damn about the opinions of Al Stump?! What people want to know about is Ty Cobb! direction.raw_text: The second version, my version, was written on legal pads and hotel stationery and cocktail napkins and anything I could scrape together without drawing his attention... (beat) I kept my version in a box at the bottom of my suitcase -- (CONTINUED) 86. 92   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stump packs "his" version into a box, hiding it deep in his suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole thing had become an agonizing death watch, and most days I couldn't believe the son of a bitch wouldn't die... The door flies open and Cobb bursts in -- full of vim and vigor, a fresh set of clothes on, fire in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing like a cigarette girl and thirty hours of sleep to invigorate a man, Stumpy! You look like shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Been writing, Ty... Cobb goes straight for the typewriter and yanks out a page, grabbing the stack of typed pages as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well let's see how we're doing... Cobb reads the pages with utter seriousness.       Stump watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, God damn it, Stumpy, yes! Now you're getting it! None of this Sigmund Freud bullshit! Baseball, Stumpy, baseball! Yes! Cobb rushes to Stump and embraces him, almost like a child. His eyes are wet with tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You understand! People are no damn good but you're different! You're okay, Stumpy, you get it! (beat) And I can trust you... Stump stares back.    And nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now let's go roll us some dice, Alimony, I feel a hot hand coming on!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 87. 93   INT. CASINO - NIGHT                                           93 Cobb and Stump approach the gaming tables and as they do, Cobb is recognized and approached for autographs. He signs as he walks, suddenly gracious in this moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'see how it    works, Stumpy... they boo ya your    whole career, then when you're    about to kiss off, they put ya    on a pedestal. That's what being a    legend's all about. Arriving at a craps table, Cobb barges right in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Send the dice to the Peach, boys, and belly up to the bar... The croupier pushes the dice to Cobb who places a bet, as do the others. Cobb rolls the dice -- but he sees something.     Somebody.

direction.raw_text: Mona!   You with that nigger! Cobb's voice silences the tables.    Ramona looks up.

direction.raw_text: I know.

direction.raw_text: Willie!     Is she with you?! (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: This is my man, Mr. Cobb, and he's all man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My girl with my nigger!

direction.raw_text: She's not your girl and he's not your -- Cobb pulls his gun and tries to climb across the table.

direction.raw_text: Mr. Cobb!

direction.raw_text: What is the world coming to?! BLAM, BLAM, BLAM -- the gun is FIRED REPEATEDLY into the ceiling fixtures, into the mirrors above the tables. Cobb is wrestled to the table by several men, including Stump. And it takes all of them to escort the struggling Cobb out of the casino into the lobby.

direction.raw_text: We're leaving, we're leaving! There's no reason to press charges!

direction.raw_text: Do you know who I am?!

direction.raw_text: Back off, God damn it!   We're leaving!

direction.raw_text: Where we going, Stumpy, I wanta find us some more women! Stump hesitates, chaos swirls around them. Cobb is out of control, we hear threats of arrest -- when...

direction.raw_text: . 96   CONTINUED:                                                     96 COBB Y'know something, Alimony, I believe you're the best friend I ever had.

direction.raw_text: I was disturbed, to say the least, that he felt we were friends -- but at least for the moment it made things bearable. (beat) And he started talking -- the world according to Ty Cobb... Cobb talks into a tape recorder sitting on his lap, enjoying the hand microphone.

direction.raw_text: And then this fat ass named Babe Ruth came into the league and damn near destroyed the game of baseball... We all thought he was gonna eat and fuck his way outta the league but he hung around for a few years -- STUMP 'Hung around'? He was -- (quickly revising)

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 96    CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't care that they cheered and adored Ruth -- I cared that they respected his ballplaying -- Christ, they built Yankee Stadium for him with a 297-foot right field line. My sister Florence could hit the ball 297 feet!
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whenever we got into a fight with the New Yorkers, 24 of our guys would fight 24 of their guys and me and Ruth would take on each other! As the benches clear -- Cobb races not at the pitcher but straight to right field where The Babe is charging in like a rhino straight for Cobb. Somewhere near second base the two giants collide in a thunderous smash, falling to the ground in a brawl, as 48 players slug it out in the b.g.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Ty...

HALL OF FAME BUILDING - NIGHT                           109 A crowd of locals has gathered and is cheering as the great old warriors of baseball get out of one limo after another and pass a phalanx of security guards, television cameras, and photogaphers. A P.A. ANNOUNCER presents each one. P.A. ANNOUNCER The great left-handed pitcher from the New York Giants, who struck out five men in a row in the 19-- All-Star game -- Carl Hubbell. Lanky Carl Hubbell, 50's, waves to the crowd and cameras as he enters to applause from the locals gathered. P.A. ANNOUNCER The great third baseman from the Chicago Cubs, Harold Joseph 'Pie' Traynor... Pie Traynor, 60's, struggles to the entrance using a cane. P.A. ANNOUNCER Paul and Lloyd Waner, the Waner brothers -- Big Poison and Little Poison -- from the Pittsburgh Pirates... The Waner Brothers, 60's, jauntily wave and enter. P.A. ANNOUNCER Fifty-eight home runs in a season -- Mr. Double-X -- the great Jimmy Foxx! The barrel-chested Jimmy Foxx, 60, gets out and waves. P.A. ANNOUNCER And ladies and gentlemen, the highest lifetime batting average of all time, first man elected to the Hall of Fame, retired with over 90 batting records, the one and only Georgia Peach, Ty Cobb! Cobb gets out, followed by Stump. Cobb walks into the building, past the cameras, utterly erect and upright, stretching his full six feet one inch. The applause is the most enthusiastic yet. (CONTINUED) 99. 109   CONTINUED:                                                       109 CLOSE ON COBB'S FACE His concentration is intense, his focus is mesmerizing, full of pride and rage. He makes it to the door.

direction.raw_text: Welcome to Cooperstown, ladies and gentlemen. We're here to acknowledge the greatest ballplayers of all time, those men still gracing our presence who were among the earliest inductees into the Hall of Fame. (beat) Waner, Hubbell, Foxx, Cochrane, Hornsby, Traynor -- these are the giants, the Old Masters of our craft... The spotlight moves around the room and each man waves, half rising from his chair.

direction.raw_text: But the greatest of all is with us tonight -- simply put, the best ballplayer ever -- Tyrus Raymond Cobb. A spotlight hits Cobb, who rises and waves to the crowd as the lights dim.

Cobb stares at his old uniform. Stump stares at Cobb. And Cobb starts crying, softly at first, then swelling until the muffled deep, convulsive sounds become more audible. He starts crying like a baby. Stump stands quietly nearby, afraid to move, until, finally: (CONTINUED) 110. 133   CONTINUED:                                                       133 Cobb sucks up the tears and finally turns to Stump.

direction.raw_text: That's all.

direction.raw_text: I was raised in the Baptist Church but I know that Heaven is just the ol' oskefagus -- the change-up. You swing from your ass 'cause you think life is a fastball down the middle and after your bat has crossed the plate and you're all off balance and looking stupid, the ball just kinda flutters across home, slow and juicy and hittable, and as it crosses the plate, the ball looks at you and smiles a nasty smile and laughs its way into the catcher's mitt... (beat) We don't just lose -- we're made fools of.

direction.raw_text: I'm just doing a job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love my wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all loved our wives, Al, that's got nothing to do with it. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 149   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll find somebody else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a million broads out there, Stumpy -- put down the gun. KABLAM! Stump FIRES at the man but the shot goes wild. He's drunk, he's not experienced with guns, he's shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not going to accommodate this man, Tyrus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're all mixed up.   Give me the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're absolutely right, Tyrus, I've been accommodating people my whole life and it stops right here. (beat) You've killed a man. I'll kill a man. KABLAM!   KABLAM!   He misses again. The Man drops to his knees, begging for his life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Please, dear God! I have a family, too!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't give me that sob-sister stuff! Stump tries to hold the gun with two hands, approaching the man, to nearly point-blank range.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Al... no... Al... Al... Stump looks crazed, a bathrobe falling open, his feet bare and wet, his hair awry from the rainstorm. He aims the gun at the man's head, looks at Cobb with wild glee. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 149   CONTINUED:    (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Life is too short to be diplomatic. A man's friends don't care what he says or does. You're my friend, Ty, right? You're my friend!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Stump pulls the TRIGGER -- CLICK.     Empty. As the Man looks up, realizing he's alive, Stump strikes him across the face with the gun, drawing blood. The Man scrambles to his feet and races from the room, grabbing his briefcase, and running to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're crazy! No wonder she wants to divorce you! You're crazy! And the Man runs into the rainy night, leaving Cobb and Stump. Stump's head collapses in his hands -- Bewildered, exhausted. The two men sit alone for several beats before Stump speaks. He is completely lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I almost killed a man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little drunken excess...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I put a gun to a man's head and pulled the trigger. I wanted to kill him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's forgotten already. I saw nothing. Nothing happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes it did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Al, listen to me. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 149   CONTINUED:    (5)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I was hired to write a biography of the greatest sportswriter of our time -- a biography of Al Stump -- would I include what happened tonight? Attorneys are pigs -- divorce attorneys are lower than pigs. What happened tonight was private. An intimacy. Your own business. Our own business. Nobody else's. It wouldn't belong in a book about greatness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody's gonna write my biography.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And when the brunette in the courtyard brushed against you, I know what happened, Al. A warm summer breeze, the smell of jasmine, her black hair against a white blouse -- you came to life again, you got hard -- and when you saw her naked it was more than you could bear... it's okay, Al, it's okay... (beat) The brunette ain't gonna be in the book either... Stump looks up at Cobb but says nothing. He picks up a nearly-empty bottle off the floor and takes a hit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the drinking? Well, they used to say ol' Ty had a drinking problem but you can booze me right under the table right now... no problem... and nobody's God damn business, either... Stump raises his hand, motioning Cobb to stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I get it... I get it... A moment.    A look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then get some sleep.   You look pathetic. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 149   CONTINUED:   (6)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stump crawls on the bed toward the pillows with the stupid grace of a drunk looking for a key under the mat. Cobb helps Stump lie down, pulling a blanket over him. Stump rolls over to go to sleep, Cobb tucks the blanket around him, and picks up the bottle from the pillow. Cobb takes a last hit of the bottle -- Finishing it off. He throws it to the ground, and looks around the room for another. COBB'S POV - STUMP'S SUITCASE lies open on a chair.   A nearly-full bottle of Scotch is visible. BACK TO SCENE He makes it to the bottle -- Steadies himself -- he's ex- hausted. He takes a deep swig from the Scotch. Several deep gulps, enough to kill a horse, but it only helps him steady himself. And he sees something in the suitcase -- He looks down at -- COBB'S POV - CARDBOARD BOX which Stump has been filling with his secret manuscript. BACK TO SCENE Cobb opens the box and pulls out a paper.   He reads it. He looks at Stump, and -- Cobb takes the box and the bottle to the chair by the fireplace, where he sits down, puts on his reading glasses, and starts reading "the real story." CLOSE ON COBB He reads page one slowly and carefully, then starts mov- ing through the box full of odd sizes of paper, hotel stationery, cocktail napkins, legal pads, all handwritten in secret. He keeps glancing up at the bed where Stump is in the deep stupor of sleep. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 149   CONTINUED:    (7)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... 'vicious, pathological, bubbling with violence... Cobb's demons were not merely exorcized on the baseball field... they spilled over into all parts of his miserable life...'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: from the text -- from Cobb's real life. A)   Cobb sharpens his spikes with a file. B)   Cobb steals second base and slides spikes high, drawing blood. C)   Cobb driving a fancy car with a pretty woman at his side. D)   Cobb beats a man to death in an alley. E)   Cobb onstage with a stripper at a smoker. F)   Cobb striking his wife and knocking her to the ground. G)   Cobb FIRING a GUN at Stump in the hunting lodge. H)   Cobb and Stump being turned away from the parties by Hornsby. I)   Cobb's father being blown away by the shotgun. J)   Cobb on third being booed -- More trash on the field. Police restrain the crowd. Cobb stands defiantly, waving the crowd away in a menacing gesture, fearlessly. The sounds of derisive booing build to a crescendo, and then...

He sees that the gun barrel is covered with blood.

direction.raw_text: No... no... no... this can't be... Absolutely not... This is not right... Cobb coughs again -- More blood covers his chin. He touches his chin, touches the blood, smears it around a little, looks at his hands now covered with blood.

direction.raw_text: Stumpy?! No... Cobb moves around the tiny bathroom like a caged animal. He falls to his knees in prayer in front of the sink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our Father, which art in heaven, hallowed by Thy name. Thy kingdom come, Thy will be done, on Earth as it is in heaven. Give us this day our daily bread, and forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive -- (beat) Aw, fuck it... little late for that sob sister stuff... Cobb rises to his feet and looks in the mirror again. He grabs a hand towel and daubs his face with it. A bit more blood trickles from his mouth. And gradually a deep calm seems to settle over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... so this is what it feels like... 153   COBB                                                            153 returns to the bedroom and sits down on the edge of the bed, next to Stump who continues his deep, drunken sleep. Cobb picks up the phone and dials as he continues mopping his chin with the towel. He speaks with great calm. (CONTINUED)

Can you please prepare your finest room for me? Tomorrow morning would be fine. Cobb hangs up and leans back on the bed next to Stump who is still deep in drunken sleep. direction.raw_text: Ty! Stump leaps out of bed and looks around. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: God... BACK TO SCENE He rushes to the fireplace where only embers now glow. He sees something -- STUMP'S POV The "real" manuscript scattered around the floor near the chair. direction.raw_text: ... Mr. Cobb.

direction.raw_text: Hey, Stumpy, where you been? You can't believe the shit they call food in this joint. You get some sleep? Good. I had quite a read last night... A Nurse enters warily, but determined, with a small sy- ringe. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Tell the son of a bitch to go downstairs and have a Pepsi -- I got no time for business. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: It's high.   What else you need to know?

direction.raw_text: I have to do it. The Young doctor wraps Cobb's arm with the device and begins pumping. Another OLDER DOCTOR enters and addresses Cobb head on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Cobb. We cannot allow you to have a gun in here. Cobb picks up the gun and aims it at the doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come and get it. The Older Doctor turns and leaves.        Stump enjoys the show.

direction.raw_text: Y'know, Stumpy, my oldest son was a doctor -- a hacksaw artist, that's all they are -- (increasing rage) He died of a brain tumor when he was forty -- hadn't spoke to me in fifteen years 'cause I was such a rotten father -- put that in your God damn book! The Younger Doctor completes his task and slips away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bad, ain't it? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 158   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know which version of your life I'm going to publish. I really don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There ya go again! Accommodating me and you don't have to! I died faster than you could write! Cobb waves his gun just as some more doctors enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get the hell outta here! Everybody but Stumpy! Out! The room clears -- leaving only Cobb and Stump.

direction.raw_text: You fooled me, Stumpy, nobody ever fooled me but you pulled it off! I thought we were pals!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know what I was getting into with this job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quit explaining yourself! Stand by your convictions! You beat the great Ty Cobb! I respect that! But if you print it -- print it all! (beat) My second son weighed 300 pounds and he died of a heart attack in the arms of a hooker in Paso Robles. My other son I lost all track of and my two daughters won't speak to me and my two ex- wives won't and my siter you know won't! Print it all! (beat) And Ty Cobb can't get it up anymore! Print that too!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all... confusing... (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: It's not! It's simple! You won! Tell the world that the greatest ballplayer who ever lived was also the biggest bastard! Who cares now?! I give you permission and my blessing! From here on it's your story! Stump nods and pulls a pint of whiskey from his coat pocket. He goes up to Cobb and tucks the whiskey under the blanket.

direction.raw_text: Here's a little something might help. Cobb nods in appreciation.

direction.raw_text: Where's my money?
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stumpy, there's nothing wrong with wanting glory. (beat) Now get the hell outta here. Stump places Cobb's hand on his money, nods, and -- Stump leaves the room without looking back at -- COBB IN BED with a gun -- in the last stages of life, his health in total collapse, he is in complete control.
direction.name: direction
